content.text: John Stuart Mill formalized five methods for discovering causal connections. These are still used in scientific reasoning today.

content.definition: Five systematic methods for identifying causes: Agreement, Difference, Joint Method, Residues, and Concomitant Variation.

symbols.name: Common Factor
symbols.meaning: If A is present whenever effect E occurs, A may cause E
symbols.example: All sick patients ate the salad

symbols.name: Absent Factor
symbols.meaning: If A is the only difference between E occurring and not, A causes E
symbols.example: Control group without treatment didn't improve

symbols.name: Agreement + Difference
symbols.meaning: Combine both methods for stronger evidence
symbols.example: Present when E, absent when not-E

symbols.name: Remaining Cause
symbols.meaning: Subtract known causes; remainder explains the rest
symbols.example: Planet's orbit differs from prediction - unknown mass?

symbols.name: Proportional Change
symbols.meaning: If A varies with E, A probably causes E

content.title: Method of Difference
premises: Two groups are identical in all respects.
One group receives treatment A; the other doesn't.
Only the treated group shows effect E.
content.note: This is the logic behind controlled experiments and clinical trials.

content.title: Method of Agreement
premises: Five people got food poisoning at a party.
They ate different main courses, different desserts.
But they ALL ate the Caesar salad.
content.conclusion: The Caesar salad probably caused the food poisoning.
content.note: The common factor in all cases points to the cause.

content.question: You want to test if a new drug works. You give it to one group and not another, keeping everything else the same. Which method is this?
content.explanation: This is the Method of Difference. The only difference between the groups is whether they receive the drug. If only the drug group improves, the drug is the likely cause. This is the foundation of controlled experiments.
